distribution: Goiás (Brazil West-Central, Brazil, Southern America);Brasília Distrito Federal (Brazil West-Central, Brazil, Southern America);
remarks: doi:10.1600/036364424X17110456120721 Etymology: name honours Cecília Ezcurra, who has made great contributions to knowledge of South American Acanthaceae.

name: Ruellia chapadensis
remarks: doi:10.1600/036364424X17110456120721 Etymology: name refers to the location where this species was collected, inside or near to the boundaries of the Chapada dos Veadeiros National Park.

name: Ruellia curupira
distribution: Alagoas (Brazil Northeast, Brazil, Southern America);Bahia (Brazil Northeast, Brazil, Southern America);
remarks: doi:10.13102/neod.131.2 The specific epithet is named for 'Curupira' one of the most popular forest protector entities in Brazilian folklore and is represented by a child (or dwarf) with the body covered with reddish hairs and feet facing backwards. This epithet was attributed to the new species by the fact that this species inhabits the interior of the woods, as Curupira, has hispid and reddish to brownish indumentum, like Curupira's hairy body, and the inflorescences sometimes are secund, such as Curupira's backward-facing feet.

name: Ruellia eriocalyx
remarks: Suppressed work under Art.34 ICN 2018: Glaziou, A. F. M. 1905–1913. Plantae Brasiliae centralis a Glaziou lectae. Mém. Soc. Bot. France 1(3): 1–661. (TL-2 No. 2030.) [All ranks.]

name: Ruellia exserta
reference: Proc. Biol. Soc. Washington 116(2): 271 (-273; fig. 5E-H). 2003 [11 Aug. 2003]
distribution: Mato Grosso (Brazil West-Central, Brazil, Southern America);Pará, Brazil North (Brazil, Southern America);Rondônia (Brazil North, Brazil, Southern America);

name: Ruellia fulozinha
distribution: Alagoas (Brazil Northeast, Brazil, Southern America);Pernambuco (Brazil Northeast, Brazil, Southern America);
remarks: doi:10.13102/neod.131.2 The specific epithet is derived from Comadre Fulozinha [misspelling of Comadre Florzinha], a common character in the folklore of some States of northeastern Brazil (e.g. Rio Grande do Norte, Paraíba, Pernambuco) who protects the woods.

name: Ruellia glandulifolia
distribution: Goiás (Brazil West-Central, Brazil, Southern America);Brasília Distrito Federal (Brazil West-Central, Brazil, Southern America);
remarks: doi:10.1600/036364424X17110456120721 Etymology: name refers to the remarkable sticky glandular-pubescent indumentum of the leaves.

name: Ruellia hatschbachii
remarks: doi:10.1600/036364424X17110456120721 Etymology: name honours Gerdt Guenther Hatschbach, a great Brazilian botanist from Museu Botanico de Curitiba, who has collected more than 82,000 specimens during his life.

name: Ruellia insurrecta
remarks: doi:10.13102/neod.131.2 The specific epithet originates from the Latin 'insurrectio', which means insurgent. The name is in honour of Quilombo dos Palmares, the most iconic refuge of African slaves and its descendant in Brazil, which resisted for almost a century (from 1633 to 1697) to the attacks of the Portuguese Kingdom (Espindola 1871). The Quilombo dos Palmares was settled in the surrounding areas of where the new species is found.

name: Ruellia jiboia
distribution: Alagoas (Brazil Northeast, Brazil, Southern America);Bahia (Brazil Northeast, Brazil, Southern America);
remarks: doi:10.13102/neod.131.2 The specific epithet 'jiboia' comes from the Old Tupi language 'mboîa' and means snake. This name is widely applied to South American boid snakes, especially to Boa constrictor. The epithet was attributed due to the uncommon climbing habit in Ruellia, alluding to a snake.

name: Ruellia kalungae
remarks: doi:10.11646/phytotaxa.635.1.6 Etymology: named in tribute to the 'Kanluga Community', Traditional Quilombola Peoples from the state of Goiás, protectors of the local nature for at least 300 years.

name: Ruellia lucindae
remarks: doi:10.1600/036364424X17110456120721 Etymology: name honours Lucinda Ann McDade, renowned expert in Acanthaceae systematics, for her many contributions to knowledge of the family and to systematic biology generally.

name: Ruellia mellosilvae
remarks: doi:10.1600/036364424X17110456120721 Etymology: name honors Renato de Mello-Silva (in memoriam), who made great contributions in the knowledge of Brazilian Flora.

name: Ruellia pinguicula
remarks: doi:10.1600/036364424X17110456120721 Etymology: name refers to carnivorous plant of the genus Pinguicula L. (Lentibulariaceae) whose leaves are congested and covered by glandular trichomes, similar to the bracts of R. pinguicula.

name: Ruellia taboleirana
distribution: Rio Grande do Norte (Brazil Northeast, Brazil, Southern America);Alagoas (Brazil Northeast, Brazil, Southern America);
remarks: doi:10.13102/neod.131.2 The specific epithet refers to the environment where the species occurs, 'Tabuleiros litorâneos'.

name: Ruellia umbrosa
remarks: doi:10.11646/phytotaxa.544.1.7 Etymology: 'The specific epithet “umbrosa” from Latin umbrosus, alluding to that the species grows in a shaded environment in a riparian forest'.
